Topic.Title: Intel could win the smartphone race

Message.Msg: The new Lenovo K900 is the company’s flagship product and it uses the latest Atom as well. The 6.9mm thick stainless steel body has a 5.5” HD 400ppi screen and 13MP camera make this a desirable phone as well – alas Lenovo has no intention to bring it to Australia either. ZTE (a Chinese OEM that makes some of Telstra’s wireless modems) has announced that its Grand X2 (pictured) will be powered by the Intel Atom running at 2GHz. We may see this very powerful smartphone as a Telstra own brand later this year. The Atom was chosen as it was the fastest currently available system on a chip and its low battery drain. Intel’s new Clover Trail+ 32 bit Atom CPU’s for Android are gaining popularity with the ASUS FonePad Note 6, Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1” and Asus Transformer Book Trio taking the Intel route. But the new Atom Bay Trail (22 nm Silvermont) due out very soon may seal the deal for Intel over ARM. This is a 2.1GHz quad core, 64 bit processor with Intel’s Ivy Bridge GPU that is reputed to be 3x faster than the Z2580 and will be optimised for Android Key Lime Pie. Not satisfied Intel has also announced a 14nm Airmont quad core for 2014. These specifications are well ahead of anything ARM has announced. From ITWire

Message.Title: What We Know Now
Message.Msg: What we know now is that Intel is getting traction across the board. The Apple show at WWDC was proof of this where Intel technology was the only hardware excitement present. Sure there were some nice new software features but the real computing power coming to the Mac Pro was the best example of what Apple is capable of - with Intel's help. The Mac upgrades were a very nice extension of the traction from the Haswell announcement, Computex and the huge number of new product releases. And all of this leads nicely into Intel's roadmap for the rest of the year with back-to-school traction and holiday sales traction and then what will be monumental excitement over the arrival of Intel's volume production of 14nm at the beginning of 2014. We know now that the big Wall Street firms are going to do everything in their power to try to #$%$ the Intel ramp. We've seen this repeatedly lately and we've seen it substantially fail. Intel has huge positive press now and it seems clear that there is real excitement over the new performance coupled with new form factors. We know now that ARM investors have recognized the Intel threat and know that it is real to the extent of a 20 percent drop in the ARM stock price. We know now that we have the Samsung deal to add to the Altera deal and the Mac upgrades. More information on that at the June 20th Samsung event. Across the entire computing spectrum, Intel is on the move and gaining ground consistently. The tipping point has been reached and the ARM era is coming to a close. 2013: Year of the Intel Tablet 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone

Message.Title: HP DISCOVER: HP UNVEILS WHISPER-QUIET HASWELL-POWERED MICROSERVER
Message.Msg: HP launched three servers for small and medium businesses at its Discover conference in Las Vegas Tuesday. All three are single-processor servers powered by the latest Haswell chips Intel announced one week ago. HP designed the eighth-generation ProLiant MicroServer for use in an office with 10 or fewer employees. The ProLiant M310e Gen8 v2 is a tower server geared mainly for remote and branch offices, and the ProLiant DL320e Gen8 v2 is a rack server designed with smaller-than-usual depth to fit in as many kinds of spaces as possible. The ProLiant DL320e Gen8 v2 rack server is about 15 inches deep, which means it can be installed in small spaces, running applications for small businesses, chain stores, factory automation, medical, transportation, telecom and military. This is the first time HP has built a server of this size. “That's actually a new form factor for us,” Glass said. The new ML310e server is basically a version of its predecessor upgraded with one of the new Intel Xeon E3-1200 v3 chips. The new MicroServer's starting price is about US$500, and the ML310e (the tower) and the DL320e start at $870 and $900, respectively. From datacenterdynamics

Message.Title: The new MacBook Air with Haswell on the way
Message.Msg: My laptop collection is about to get larger as I couldn't pass on the new MacBook Air with the Haswell processor from Intel. The new processor is powerful and almost doubles the battery life of the new MacBook Air compared to the last generation model. That combination was too good for me to pass up, so an 11-inch MacBook Air will soon be arriving at my door. The biggest update to the new MacBook Air comes with the latest processor from Intel, the Haswell. I have been anxious to get my hands on a Haswell-equipped laptop and I am excited the MacBook Air will be that device. The Core i5 Haswell processor in the MacBook Air comes standard with a 1.3 GHz processor but a 1.7 GHz option is available. The Haswell processor upgrades the graphics to the Intel HD 5000. This is reported to be 40 percent faster than the HD 4000 used in most laptops today. The most significant improvement in the new MacBook Air is the extended battery life due to the Haswell processor. Apple is quoting 9 hours for the 11.6-inch model compared to 5 hours in the previous model. My experience with Apple products is the quoted battery life is very close to what you actually get, unlike the case with some other vendors. This battery life should get me through an entire day away from an outlet, even with heavy usage. Summary: Apple announced the next generation MacBook Air with the new Intel Haswell processor that almost doubles battery life. By James Kendrick for Mobile News

Message.Title: "That is about to change, and this time it's for real..."
Message.Msg: The ARM Singularity Intel (INTC) has been trying to break into the mobile markets for quite some time. It even got close with a few design wins from friendly OEMs like Motorola or Lenovo (LNVGY.PK). But in reality it never really broke through. ARM (ARMH) designs always kept a strong hold on 90%+ of the market, no matter what. That is about to change, and this time it's for real I'm not even talking about the present Clover Trail+ design wins, namely with the new Samsung Galaxy Tab 3. This is already significant because Samsung is a first tier OEM and is certainly not giving Intel this win because of its friendly nature. Samsung is doing something predictable taking into account the latest benchmarks (on a Lenovo K900), which show Clover Trail+ to be competitive with the present smartphones at the highest end. But as I said, Clover Trail+ is not the reason why I'm penning this article. Intel's Silvermont architecture, which will be on products before 2013 is out, is the real singularity about to hit ARM. This architecture is entirely new, and showcases Intel's superiority both in product and process technology. The same superiority which relegated AMD to "also-ran" status. From Paulo Santos

Topic.Title: "That is about to change, and this time it's for real..."

Message.Msg: The possible catalyst which might open the floodgates While the performance and power consumption specs, by themselves, are probably enough to extend Intel's penetration into the market well beyond what Clover Trail+ will manage, the really large impact will probably come all at once. This impact will come from the likely adoption by Intel either during the iPhone 6 cycle in 2014, or most likely during the 2015 cycle. The reason is simple. Apple (Apple) greatly values power consumption, as seen from the way it kept the iPhone's ARM-based CPU at 800Mhz long beyond necessary. Apple is thus highly likely to spring for the state-of-the-art if it guarantees it outstanding power consumption, which Silvermont seems likely to. Also, Apple is already using Intel in its OSX products, and would probably gain efficiencies internally from concentrating on a single architecture. The wildcard would obviously be backward compatibility, though re-compiling apps would probably enable it. Thus, on the day Apple decides to go with Intel on mobile, ARM will instantly lose around 25% of the smartphone market in one single blow. While the market could conceivably accept slow erosion, such hit would be impossible to ignore.

Topic.Title: "That is about to change, and this time it's for real..."

Message.Msg: Intel's further wildcard Another wildcard is the fact that Intel will bring down its Haswell architecture to fanless tablets. A fanless tablet with the kind of power Haswell provides will blow everything else out of the water. The main problem with Microsoft's Surface Pro could be said to be the fact that it still has a fan, which makes it much thicker and heavier, as well as less reliable. At the class of power Haswell provides we already know no other company is able to field a competitive product, so this also effectively cuts ARM's wings above Silvermont (if it were able to field anything there). Further implications ARM is just the IP vendor for ARM CPUs, but these are then produced by a multitude of OEMs. Of these, several trade in the stock market, including Qualcomm (QCOM) and Nvidia (NVDA). Intel's forceful entry into the mobile market isn't just negative for ARM, it's also deeply negative for these vendors. From Paulo Santos

Topic.Title: "That is about to change, and this time it's for real..."

Message.Msg: Conclusion Intel has reached parity with Clover Trail+, and is now getting ready to launch Silvermont before the year is out. Silvermont seems likely to finally be wildly superior to anything that ARM is fielding this year or next, so Silvermont is likely to give Intel its much-coveted beachhead into the mobile market. Not only that, but Silvermont's superiority seems so large, and its upgrade schedule is so aggressive, that most probably Intel will switch towards it either during 2014, or most likely in 2015. When this happens, ARM will lose 25% of the worldwide smartphone market in a single hit. These developments are positive for Intel and deeply negative for ARM, which to make matters worse trades at a huge valuation premium - its EV/EBITDA stands at 45.3 times. But it doesn't stop there. These developments are also significantly negative for OEMs producing ARM on a license, like Qualcomm and Nvidia. The current design wins by Intel mean the dam has been breached, when Silvermont arrives the floodgates will surely open. From Paulo Santos

Topic.Title: Apple:Writing on the wall for ARM

Message.Msg: The day that Apple goes full Intel is the day that they are never coming back to ARM. I know what you are saying about not wanting to have a touch screen on a home based PC. Still being a one OS company is the holy grail of all ideas for Microsoft and Apple, even Linux based companies like Google and Ubuntu. There are a few reasons why. #1. Developers would only have to develop on one platform per company. Microsoft's metro apps have to be designed differently for RT versus x86. If you want it to work on Windows Phone that's a yet another app. Developing for one platform per company will make attracting developers an easier task. #2. One user experience across the board. If someone was comfortable working an iPhone and they really liked it then the Mac sale would be much easier. If they can freely navigate their phone then the same would be true of their laptop computer. #3. Apple could focus on one and only one operating system at a time. Having two major OS's at the same time is like managing different companies. The issue for Microsoft has become Windows 8 is wonderful if you have a touch device, but is horrible if you don't. The problem has been that for phones and tablets we want simplicity, and for desktops we demand more complexity. I believe that nobody really wants to touch their desktop monitors. We are used to mice and we're never giving it up. I believe Apple is starting to move in the direction it needs to go by offering shared look and feel between iOS 7 and OS/X Maverics. Where I see thing going is that your phone will put out more complex menus when hooked up to an external keyboard and mouse. Your phone will be more like OS/X when plugged in, and will simplify down the iOS look and feel for the touch screen experience when it's being used in the smartphone mode. Doing this in a manner that is intuitive is something I believe Apple can do very well.

Topic.Title: Apple:Writing on the wall for ARM

Message.Msg: #1. Developers would only have to develop on one platform per company. Microsoft's metro apps have to be designed differently for RT versus x86. ---- If you build a metro app, it'll work on ARM and x86 - as a developer you don't care. It's the store that distributes the app, so it handles the ISA issue. If Apple goes x86, it'll use the same approach. Microsoft has shown that a touch UI doesn't work well in a WIMP environment, so you need to have a different UI for touch. The kernel of iOS/OSx is effectively the same, just different API's/UI's.

Topic.Title: How many millions did Intel waste on intel TV?

Message.Msg: Intel has a long history of this. They are always looking elsewhere for sources of new growth, but nothing ever works and the end up making all their money o he processor business. Many may not recall, but for a while in the 1990s and into the earlier 2000s they sold an Intel branded MP3 player and and Intel branded digital camera (intended to take advantage of their flash memory production) and for a while they sold a whole line of Intel branded home and small business networking equipment. You could go to the store and buy an "Intel" router. They need to still with their core competency of manufacturing microprocessors which, fortunately, they do for the most part and they do that very well. But it seem to be human nature (not just at Intel) to be looking at what the other guy is doing. "The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence." So some genius at Intel looks around and sees Google, Netflix, Apple, Amazon, Hulu, Microsoft, etc. all getting into the delivery of video content to televisions and the Intel guys say, "we should get in on that too." Who cares that it is a completely different type of business than what Intel has always done? These things come and go and I doubt the money they spent makes even a tiny dent in their financials.

Message.Title: Intel Has A Secret Version Of Haswell
Message.Msg: I would like to thank InvestorsHub long-timer wbmw for bringing the following to my attention. Intel (INTC) recently released the data sheets for its ultra low power editions of its "Haswell" processor aimed for Ultrabooks and even high end tablets. While Intel has been bragging that its latest "Haswell" designs can be configured to have a 6W "SDP" (which basically means "when the chip is behind the glass, throttle/manage the frequencies so that the chip does not consume more than 6W on average"), it seems that the company has actually been a little shy in its PR statements. Intel's own data sheet acknowledges the existence of yet another "Haswell" - a 4.5W SDP part. The 4.5W Part For Fanless Tablets Straight from the data sheet, here is the evidence for the existence of this other "Haswell" part: (click to enlarge) The implications of this part are enormous. While it seemed likely that a 6W SDP part would be enough for 13" fanless tablets/detachables and even fanless clamshells, the 4.5W SDP part would likely be capable of driving a fanless 11.6" tablets and convertibles with good battery life. While the performance against, say, a 15W or 11.5W unrestricted TDP "Haswell," will likely be appreciably lower, such devices would still very likely be significantly faster than the best ARM (ARMH) based devices in competing form factors due to the sophistication of the design/process technology superiority. From Ashraf Eassa

Topic.Title: Intel Has A Secret Version Of Haswell

Message.Msg: A Pincer Attack On ARM & Its Partners It seems that Intel is, in the words of a good friend of mine, executing a classic "pincer" attack on the ARM world. Attack from below with "Silvermont," which should be faster and lower power than ARM's finest, and then attack from above with the "Core" micro-architecture with even higher performance levels at similar power consumption levels. The interesting thing about "Haswell" is the dramatic idle power consumption improvements that it brought to bear on the same process generation as "Ivy Bridge," implying a Herculean effort on the micro-architecture and physical design side of things, to substantially widen the dynamic range. In particular, while "Ivy Bridge" CPU + PCH consumed 3.2W - 3.4W (again, thank you, wbmw) in their deepest idle states, "Haswell" reduces this down to mere milliwatts: (click to enlarge) So, what we have here is a family of high performance processors that can idle nearly as low as the very best smartphone processors. This dynamic range in a high performance processor is unheard of and is a very dramatic advancement in the state of micro-processors. Keep in mind that these idle numbers don't just include the processor, but the on-package 32nm PCH - so there's still some room to drive things down further. From Ashraf Eassa

Topic.Title: Intel Has A Secret Version Of Haswell

Message.Msg: Conclusion This is why I have been so bullish on Intel, and this is why it is ever-frustrating when the press and sell-side don't "get it." While some outfits, particularly PC enthusiast sites, are off making claims about Haswell running too hot when overclocked (this is preposterous as overclocking is running the chip way out of specification), the fact is that "Haswell" redefines the dynamic range of what a high performance, high end processor can do. The highest end fanless tablets will feature "Core" processors, as well as the sleekest, thinnest Ultrabooks and notebooks. Sure, the overclockers on the (dying) desktop platforms will see their overclocking headrooms contract, but Intel is moving to where the market is going - mobile - and doing so in a wildly ambitious fashion. From Ashraf Eassa

Topic.Title: How many millions did Intel waste on intel TV?

Message.Msg: I don't fault Intel for being entrepreneurial, innovative companies should be willing to take risk. However, Intel's Web TV plan as announced demonstrates a serious lack of understanding of the entertainment industry and the critical factors necessary to compete in this market. The Web TV project has the look of a project hatched by tech geeks with technology looking for a problem to solve, yet completely devoid of any meaningful industry experience. It should be no surprise that Comcast is launching its own competitor to Apple TV and hence pre-empt Intel's Web TV. And it should be no surprise that Intel is finding it difficult to negotiate content deals that make good business sense. As I said before on this topic, the incumbent cable companies enjoy too many regulatory and market advantages in the U.S. for any hardware vendor (Intel or Apple) to use the cable's own infrastructure to successfully compete against them for delivery of live TV. It's not going to happen, at least not this decade. Intel should just shutdown the Web TV streaming plan and try to find a more realistic way to get their silicon inside TV's and entertainment products. I'm not concerned about the money spent on the project, it's likely too small to matter, but I would rather see them focused on opportunities they have a reasonable chance of succeeding.

Topic.Title: How many millions did Intel waste on intel TV?

Message.Msg: The control cable companies have been given over cable infrastructure (which use public right-of-way) and the video and data services delivered is unquestionably anti-competitive. The problem for Intel, Apple or Google is that the status quo, however anti-competitive, is supported by the FCC, Congress, State regulatory bodies and the courts - essentially everyone that matters. These projects cannot survive without cable cooperation but there's no reason for cable companies to partner with them. The cable companies can acquire all the technology they need. I'm not saying this is the way it should be - it's simply the reality today and no full-service live streaming project that exists today can survive long enough to see the policies change.

Topic.Title: Apple will announce Intel on its Ipads this year, with Baytrail.

Message.Msg: I know little of the Apple code- app store- device process, but after a quick google, it looks like as a developer you compile to specific revision of the ISA (ie, ARMv7 for the later stuff), so as long as Apple added an option to compile for x86 then that would solve a bulk of problems. You would expect this to happen before a device is launched, otherwise no apps. The low level stuff (assembly code) is typically for the SIMD instructions (NEON), so image manipulation, graphics libraries, game engines that kind of stuff. This would be hard to emulate/translate and maintain any level of performance. Stackoverflow has some interesting questions/answers regarding assembly code usage under ios.

Topic.Title: Apple will announce Intel on its Ipads this year, with Baytrail.

Message.Msg: Thanks for these good points. I still don't see Apple announcing something like that in advance of the hardware demo. More likely they will work with some developers in advance and keep things secret and, assuming they are able to provide tools to allow quick and easy recompilation of ARM code to x86, it probably would not take long to get a critical mass of ready-to-go apps available for when the device (new iPad) actually goes on sale. They usually have the demo about two weeks before the product goes on sale. They could stretch that to three or four weeks by doing the demo earlier (using the apps from their "partners" who will have had advanced access) so that they will have apps to show at the product announcement event. Then, the device goes on sale two to four weeks later during which other developers can recompile code. Of course, I could be completely wrong about this. Also, I still think it is likely that they will stick with ARM for the next generation of iPads using A7 processors and make the switch to Intel in the Fall of 2014 after the next generation of Intel processors are available which will be even more energy efficient than the just reased ones. Basically, the newly announced Intel processors are roughly on par with ARM so whether Apple uses ARM or Intel this year is not of much consequence, but by Fall of 2014, Intel's processors will be clearly superior to ARM-based processors and Apple will have to adopt Intel's processors to remain competitive. I figure there is a chance we might see Intel in, at least, full-sized iPads this Fall, but it seems more likely that will happen in the Fall of 2014. Disclosure: I am long INTC and AAPL.

Topic.Title: How many millions did Intel waste on intel TV?

Message.Msg: Merlot, I know you have been lukewarm on this idea since this was announced by Erik Huggers (spelling?) at Intel Media due to the privacy issue (embedded camera) as well as other competitive challenges. I am aware of the huge challenges Intel faces in all areas of providing this service: Content, Delivery, Billing, Customer Service, etc. It would be highly remiss of Intel to have not thought through the various issues in transmission of video over cable/dsl/wireless -- and developed solutions (in-house or licensed) to address these issues. Intel has said that they want to make video delivery ubiquitous - over cable lines, DSL, and wireless mobile. Though I don't claim to know the details, public carriers are required to provide access to third-parties who wish to use the carrier infrastructure. That's why we have so many mobile providers (Walmart, Cricket, Virgin, etc.) who use AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint infrastructure to deliver their services. I suspect Intel may be able to work some deals with AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint/Clearwire based on this. Further, I wouldn't be surprised if Intel has develop or licensed any special compression algorithms which would allow better streaming of video data to its set-top box. Also, if Intel manages to come out with a decent offering, it may well be able to acquire some companies in this area to round out its service and develop some management capabilities in parallel. Just some thoughts on how Intel may be able to pull this off. We'll see what happens.

Topic.Title: How many millions did Intel waste on intel TV?

Message.Msg: I have no doubt Intel is capable of doing billing, streaming content and optimizing codec technologies to reduce some of the bandwidth needed to deliver live content. I don't underestimate what Intel is good at doing. But the plan to stream live TV requires access to infrastructure and content they have to get from the very same regulated monopolies they would be competing with and those assets will not be made available to Intel, or any outside competitor on a competitive basis. See the previous posts regarding the un-level playing field regarding use of cable Internet bandwidth. Intel has access to a new codec which can help reduce bandwidth requirements around the margins but it doesn't change the overall outcome, not for cable Internet and it sure doesn't solve the issue for slower forms of transport such as DSL or anything mobile wireless where bandwidth is far more limited and controlled by the carriers. And no, I don't assume that because Intel has spent considerable money chasing this that they have some secret solution to this problem. Nothing has changed to eliminate the market advantage cable companies enjoy and there's nothing on the horizon to believe that this will change in time to save Intel's live TV streaming aspirations. And if one looks at Intel's history it is clear they invested considerable cash and energy into other misguided and mismanaged projects that had no more chance of success than this. And I say this with great fondness for the company. Note, I didn't even mention Intel's camera and facial recognition plans to monitor family members in the privacy of their homes. Given the present circumstances I think it is safe to say that the American public will think very hard before introducing another more intrusive surveillance device in their homes.

Message.Title: New Comcas Modems with Intel inside
Message.Msg: Just more $$$$$$ for Intel. Are These the Comcast Routers You're Looking for? By Anders Bylund | More Articles June 12, 2013 | Comments (0) Comcast just introduced a far more powerful cable modem, boasting gigabit download speeds and digital video decoding right in the box. With this tool in your wiring closet, you can match the bandwidth of Verizon FiOS customers, thus joining the next generation of high-speed networking without abandoning your trusty coaxial cable fee. It's so powerful, Intel wanted to brag on providing the Atom-style chips that power this new beast. Oh, and Comcast diverted some of that extra processing and networking horsepower to provide a secondary Wi-Fi network for other Comcast customers in or near your home. That move is a tantalizing blend of convenient network access for your guests and potential liability for the host. In the video below, Fool contributor Anders Bylund discusses what the new Comcast Xfinity gateway might mean for the future of high-speed consumer-grade networking. Let's just say that Google is licking its chops as Comcast gives its users more ways to find Big G's online ads.

Convincing vendors and cable companies to use Intel chips in the cable company-supplied gear is the strategy Intel can win and should pursue. The same goes for getting Intel chips inside TV's and other consumer electronic devices. But to be clear, this is not the Intel branded live TV streaming service Intel's Media Group and Eric Huggers is championing.

Intel is part of every significant INDEX and its day to day trading is highly influenced by ETF (market) trading. Message.Msg: WW - the shills only come out when there is money to be made... I take their slow but steadily increasing volume of posting as a sign that the market makers, hedge funds, and/or large brokerages wish to dimimish the possibility that common folk will be able to catch educational posts from the likes of you, aa, semi-junkie, etc... If you want to see how #$%$ up a board can get from the shills and (most likely) robo-posters, look at BAC. Don't waste your time with the shills... That's what the ignore button is for. And when they come out in mass the day before action like today, I can't help but think that they are part of an organized effort to shake shares and options from "weak" hands. The stock price went down today. And it went down enough to trigger many stops... Tomorrow it, most likely, will go up again, and those who want to buy their shares back will do so at a higher price. It happens all the time. So much so that I can't accept that the market functions freely. It seems that the path is pre-determined by some manager who tells some button pusher to make the machines bring the stock price to X by this time... I'm sure there is some programmer who knows exactly how it works but signed gag order on his work... But as you have said before, at some point fundementals will eventually have to rule. It may not be until later in 2014 (3rd or 4th qtr) when the competition has been proven out researched and manufactured, AND the market data shows INTC owning the market. Despite what you post, I believe the next big event is the July earnnigs report. Everything else has been leaked, or is baked into the price. Shares won't pop before then, and depending on how the market gods decide to spin the report, in context of the reports of ARMH, and others, may not pop then. But the 4th quarter, IMHO, holds promise... Hold your shares, or position accordingly.

Message.Title: 500 Million PCs Forecasted To Ship In 2013 On Surging Tablet Sales
Message.Msg: HotHardware 500 Million PCs Forecasted To Ship In 2013 On Surging Tablet Sales Wednesday, June 12, 2013 - by Seth Colaner What was that we were saying about the “PC market” needing to be redefined to include tablets? More market predictions are out, and this one from Canalys includes tablets in the mix, which paints a different picture of the PC market from one that’s experiencing lagging sales to one that is simply evolving to include a wider breadth of form factors in its sales numbers. When including tablets, Canalys predicts that the PC market will see 7% year-over-year growth, from 459.6 million in 2012 to 493.1 million--nearly half a billion--in 2013. In 2017, the firm forecasts shipments of PCs to reach 713.8 million. Driving this bus will be tablets. Last year, Canalys lists desktops with 111 million units shipped, notebooks at 234 million, and tablets at 114.6 million. In 2013, both desktop and notebook shipments will dip to 105 million and 205.6 million, respectively, while tablets will jump to 182.5 million. If Canalys’ predictions for 2017 hold true, the PC landscape will be totally different; tablet shipments will explode to 456.1 million, while desktops and notebooks will drop down to 85.8 million and 171.9 million, respectively.

Topic.Title: 500 Million PCs Forecasted To Ship In 2013 On Surging Tablet Sales

Message.Msg: This underscores the point that the "PC" has been on a long and predictable path of introducing new form factors since the development of the desktop, which then added the tower, notebooks, netbooks, ultrabooks, mini's, NUCs and now tablets. The trajectory of the past 30 years has been toward smaller more mobile form factors that offer the PC experience. The tablet as a PC, the smartphone as a PC and even wearable computers are merely next steps in the PC evolution. It is difficult to see any productive discourse from the "PC is dead" crowd other than to promote the ARM dream, but now with Haswell and Silvermont that argument doesn't even work.
